This is when people (me!) start thinking that the FDA and/or Teva are colluding with Mylan. When the victim is the little guy, all the big players are suspect.

So how is a consumer to benefit under this system?  Higher prices translate into increases in out of pocket expenses and insurance premiums. Higher rebates (lower prices) translate into bigger insurer and PBM profits but nothing for consumers except...again higher premiums and less choice.

>Gov't made epi-pens mandatory in schools
>Competitor recalled
>FDA rejects potential competitor
>Insurance pays for everything so majority of consumers have no incentive to challenge price increases
>FDA prevents you from buying your own foreign epi-pens
>Patent laws make it so no one else can make a competing product
>somehow this is the "free" market's fault

And the insurance companies and the PBMs will be thrilled to lose their profits from all the discounts they've pocketed instead on passing them to their patients.

Very naive to talk about this issue without examining the role of the PBMs and Big Insurance. These two only make money if they charge higher premiums and reimburse pharma companies at a lower price. Such a project will give these two players no reason to raise premiums.

Perhaps this is an opportunity for a joint effort between philanthropy and government. One of the large philanthropy foundations (are you listening Gates, Buffet, Clinton or maybe even Trump) could fund a startup to develop a safe and affordable delivery system for generic drug epinephrine and the government could streamline the testing and approval of the system. In one or two years, a new system could be available for the same cost of an EpiPen six years ago.

Consumers win, healthcare cost decrease and Mylar profits and bonuses decrease. A win, win, win.
The problem here traces back to the Democrats.  The problem here is the FDA which is run by the Obama Administration.

"Hoping legislators can bring justice to this issue."

Many times I post snarky replies in an attempt at making people laugh but this time I can't because this definitely is no laughing matter.

When you are talking about people's lives and the justification is "free market capitalism", those making the argument that profit is supreme over all will bring up that fact that it is "legal". These people ignore the fact that what is "legal" is not necessarily "moral" or "ethical".

This problem exists because of the overwhelming importance of dark money in politics and the fact that corporations are now considered people. These corporate "citizens" have bought the very "legislators" you have high hopes of taking action.

I would not bother to hold my breath, as the fact that our "representatives" have been favoring corporate interests over the well-being of the American people has been known for years.

You really don't have to be a genius to figure it out but genius Albert Einstein summed it up nicely in his classic essay "Why Socialism?" This short essay is well worth reading by all Americans:

http://monthlyreview.org/2009/05/01/why-socialism/

For those of you too busy to take 15 minutes of your valuable time to read the essay itself I have created a short summary that one can read in a couple of minutes:

http://userctl.com/BlueVsRed/036.png

It is obvious that Congress and the Federal Courts no longer work for the American people, how else can you explain Citizen's United?

How dare Mylan use struggling patients including many children gasping for a breath of air to make billions of dollars. One of those kids could be my granddaughter should she bite into food with nuts, unknowingly. How about a bee sting on a hot summer day one second and respiratory distress the next?
What if a family cannot afford these huge deductibles?

EpiPens aren't any "oh, this might be nice to have around."
EpiPens are the difference between life and death. I'm a nurse, I know.
Epi injections in the ER probably cost little to nothing to produce, syringe and vial. But for the convenience and specific dosing in a non medical setting, individuals in dire need should be penalized with these astronomical costs?

Taking advantage of this - lowest of the low are those in charge at Mylan.
Hoping legislators can bring justice to this issue.
If monopoly is allowed to exist, then it's  profit must be tightly regulated.
And strangle the government that creates these abusive monopolies.  Don't be a sucker.

Try to stay as healthy as possible. Eat wisely. Exercise. Avoid doctors and lawyers as much as possible. Inasmuch as you can, tip the scales of health in your favor. Beyond that, push for single-payer health insurance. Vote for those who are trying to level the playing field. Don't buy into expensive restaurants and stupid TV shows. Realize that the best things in life really are free. Don't covet the crap and lifestyles portrayed in T Magazine. Get real. These are some of the ways to combat this sort of despicable behavior. In short, strangle these monsters by not needing them.

It is far overdue for the FDA to streamline the ANDA (abbreviated new drug application) process to approve generic versions of drugs near their patent expiration dates.  The EpiPen approval relies on the novel injector, not the drug itself, so critical delivery devices need to be included in such an initiative.  But like the Turing anti-toxoplasmosis drug Daraprim, the chemicals themselves are actually very cheap and very easy to make, but it costs too much to maintain licensed manufacturing capability under FDA inspection if your sales are too small.  If a generic drug has a single approved source, creating a US monopoly, the FDA should apply compulsory licensing to enable a second manufacturer to utilize the existing ANDA registration package for free, and create a real market.  For some of these old but vital drugs, with few patients, the costs to manufacture, formulate and sell could even be subsidized by charitable foundations (Gates, Clinton, Buffet) already involved in similar low-cost drug access programs outside the US.  Americans pay essentially 100% of the cost for the new drug innovation.  Maybe it's time we got a subsidized drug benefit for life-saving drugs, too?

The epipen was originally developed by Survival Technology of Bethesda, MD.  My father-in-law worked for this company for many years.  The Dept. of Defense used the injector for all troops to administer atropine, an antidote for nerve gas.  This was about 40-50'years ago.  It would not be a surprise if R&D was paid for by taxpayers.

UNETHICAL.

To Heather Bresch, the board of Mylan, and the stockholders:
Here is an exercise : You are sitting at the dinner table with your severely allergic child (let's say wheat milk, wheat, dairy, mustard(!) and oats.) You have prepared a new pasta that says "Wheat free" and to be safe, you have the same meal for the other two children. Shortly after beginning the meal, you notice that your youngest son has gone quiet: "Mom, there's something wrong with these noodles." His eyes become immediately bloodshot, his face and neck is covered in hives, and he begins wheezing, struggling for breath, and tearing at his throat (because it is closing up). You drag the children to the car; while your husband drives at breakneck speed to the hospital, you inject him with an Epi-pen because he is not doing well. there may be some projectile vomiting involved. This is very scary but your allergist said you have to do this. When you get to the ER, Heather, don't worry, when you scream " He's having an anaphylactic reaction "you go to the head of the class because your child is dying in front of you. Your child may receive another life saving dose of epinephrine, as well as IV steroids, benadryl, pepcid, etc. and probably be held overnight because a second rebound reaction can occur. Thank you so much for this life saving medication. Now what are you going to do?

Looking at things system-wise, we should at least not be surprised.

1) There is a notion in our social rulebook that says public companies (of which Mylan is one) have an obligation (perhaps "fiduciary duty") to maximize investor profits. (Well, typically corporate executives exercise that duty without ignoring their "duty to themselves" to acquire a pretty good chunk of change for themselves.)

2)There are mechanisms that sharply favor people to rise to the top in both corporate management and politics if they are a little "sociopathic" (i.e., minimally guilty about harming others and willing to freely distort the truth --Bernie Madoff being an apparent full sociopath).

Thus, free of a psychological force suppressing distortion of truth, Mylan executives make attempts to explain Mylan's behavior without pointing out that it is just doing its duty to the shareholders, and not pointing out that to change its behavior, you really would need price regulation, like just about everywhere else in the world. (I.e.,, pointing out that you would need price regulation would violate the fiduciary duty to the shareholders, and probably wouldn't be so hot for the executives "duty to themselves"-wise.)

3)Given the "sociapathic" selection factor for people at the top in politics, perhaps especially strong in the U.S., the rules on pharmaceutical pricing (and causing other pathologies in our medical system) aren't going to be fixed anytime soon.

He who is surprised is not wise.
The government, or at least the elected officials are in on the deal.  Are you taken in by their crocodile tears?
You think it's one pharma exec that's running away with the money? You think the politicians, insurance companies, the ad agencies, everyone else isn't getting fat?

Can these pharma execs be tarred & feathered?   Because no amount of public outrage at their profiteering seems to make much of a difference; and forget about the government stepping up to make them back all the way down to the reasonable prices the same items go for in Canada & elsewhere.
